box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 0px; text-align: left;
display: inline-block; font-size: 22px; font-family: Helvetica; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); line-height: 1.2; pointer-events: none; white-space: normal; overflow-wrap: normal;
div.font: The limit as seen is always defined as the number of requests/calls in a window of time. For example: Block client when server receives n calls in d time

switch.text: The limit as seen is alway...

div.style: display: flex; align-items: unsafe center; justify-content: unsafe flex-start; width: 278px; height: 1px; padding-top: 683px; margin-left: 502px;
box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 0px; text-align: left;
display: inline-block; font-size: 22px; font-family: Helvetica; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); line-height: 1.2; pointer-events: none; white-space: normal; overflow-wrap: normal;

div.div: This is problematic, as it doesn't count the time the server reserved for the request which maybe more or less important than the number of requests through the network

div.style: display: flex; align-items: unsafe flex-start; justify-content: unsafe flex-start; width: 582px; height: 1px; padding-top: 133px; margin-left: 115px;
box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 0px; text-align: left; max-height: 130px; overflow: hidden;
display: inline-block; font-size: 20px; font-family: Helvetica; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); line-height: 1.2; pointer-events: none; white-space: normal; overflow-wrap: normal;
div.p: Sits between client and server, generally deployed in server to control the client requests rate, and block the client temporarily or for ever after a defined limit is exceeded

display: inline-block; font-size: 24px; font-family: Helvetica; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); line-height: 1.2; pointer-events: none; white-space: normal; overflow-wrap: normal;

div.div: We should not ignore the number of requests in a time window, as it reflects also the processing time/buffer limits of other network tools (proxy, firewall...)

div.style: display: flex; align-items: unsafe center; justify-content: unsafe flex-end; width: 278px; height: 1px; padding-top: 704px; margin-left: 1372px;
box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 0px; text-align: right;
display: inline-block; font-size: 22px; font-family: Helvetica; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); line-height: 1.2; pointer-events: none; white-space: normal; overflow-wrap: normal;

div.font: But it is not the only factor as we saw !!! The second factor, is the time passed processing each request.
A new question raises, how to combine both factors, (boolean &&, ||, or some other way...)

switch.text: But it is not the only fac...

display: inline-block; font-size: 37px; font-family: Helvetica; color: rgb(255, 96, 38); line-height: 1.2; pointer-events: none; white-space: normal; overflow-wrap: normal;

p.font: A client can run another separate (IP, footprint) instance to check for very long returning requests !! When the client identifies the endpoints, the client can run his spamming client targeting only the long running requests.

By the way in this case, the client can even bypass the limit in diagram (1) if the limit of the number of requests in a time window is more than the number of requests needed to full-fill the time window defined by the "limiter".
